abstract: Ibrahim Parlak, Kurdish restaurant owner in Michigan, wins 90-day stay on order to deport him back to Turkey; Parlak won asylum in 1992 after fleeing Turkey to escape persecution for his involvement with Kurdistan Workers' Party, but was accused of terrorist activity after United States designated group terrorist organization; defense argues Parlak's case should be reopened under United Nations Convention Against Torture, which says people cannot be deported to nations where they are likely to be tortured.
lead_paragraph: The Kurdish restaurateur faces deportation to Turkey for past links to a separatist group, but he could suffer brutal treatment when he gets there.

headline.main: Conflict Between Turkey and Kurds Clouds the Life of a Michigan Cafe Owner
headline.print_headline: Conflict Between Turkey and Kurds Clouds the Life of a Michigan Cafe Owner

snippet: The Kurdish restaurateur faces deportation to Turkey for past links to a separatist group, but he could suffer brutal treatment when he gets there.
